speech: ['The ROI and K3, this is by far the most costly line in terms of just the dollars and the magnitude of the project, and so given that and given the current pricing environment, these returns aren’t as attractive as what we showed you on the three prior projects, but we are confident that they’re still above the cost of the capital. And of course one of the great values of K3 is this optionality that it gives us, which is the second part of your question which Joc can address.']

name: Joc O'Rourke
speech: ['Actually Larry put that a good way. I would class it as optionality rather than a specific plan. These are nonrenewable resources. The K1 and K2 resources will be depleted at some point, at which time the natural progression will be to the K3 mine. That may be quite a ways down the road, but we have the option with K3 in place to accelerate that or de-accelerate it depending on what makes the best economic sense at that time. So it will depend on market, it will depend on need, and it will depend on pricing.']

name: Joel Jackson
speech: ['Joel Jackson, BMO. I had a few quick questions. So where are we with [indiscernible] right now in terms of the expansion if the team or the JV team has approved our flotation unit to move on to next phase? Second questions, where would you be on possibly procuring some Brazilian upstream assets? And thirdly, do you think now Ma’aden, and Ma’aden II will be the price setter in India, or will be a price taker with China really setting the price?']

name: Jim Prokopanko
speech: ['Joc, do you want to take the first question about that, and I didn’t quite catch it about the flotation.']

name: Joc O'Rourke
speech: ['Well let me answer overall. I think you are asking, I mean the next phase of De Yabar [ph] will require flotation to mine the lower seams of this whole body. I would say that the De Yabar [ph] expansion is still in the engineering phase. I think it’s been driven obviously by Vale as the majority owner but I don’t expect that to be coming to a decision certainly, not in the next six to nine months.']

name: Jim Prokopanko
speech: ['You had the second question about upstream assets in Brazil, and upstream did you mean production facilities? Well, we are not likely to see ourselves owning any assets near term. Vale has the principal production facilities. Going downstream to distribution are those --we think the best approach in front of us today is Greenfields with new modern facilities in prime markets rather than acquiring what others have built over the last 10 or 15 years. The third question, you asked about delivery price out of Ma’aden and Rick do you want or Mike do you want to respond to that, Mike Rahm.']

name: Mike Rahm
speech: ['I would say that they are both price takers, price be established by the overall supply and demand but Ma’aden certainly will have an advantage into the Indian market and will achieve the better net backs of anyone I think in that market.']

name: Jim Prokopanko
speech: ['Now just to say on Ma’aden projects, its advantage gas pricing, advantage to world price, sulfur pricing and we have equal stake in the oil reserves. Its’ not like we are having to buy the oil reserves. We have a stake in phosphate and oil reserves and northern Saudi Arabia. So this is not likely to see a producer that’s going to have a lower cost phosphate price in the world at the time Ma’aden phase 2 comes on.']

name: Kevin McCarthy
speech: ['Kevin McCarthy, Bank of America Merrill Lynch. Two questions on phosphates. First in the presentation, I think you illustrated that blends and to mask and diminish the segment margins for phosphates because they are sold at a lower single digit margin and so I’m wondering whether or it would be feasible and whether you have considered separating out blends for financial reporting purposes. And then second question, would you comment briefly on the breakup of PhosChem, in terms of the causes and consequences?']

name: Jim Prokopanko
speech: ['Larry, can you speak to the segregation of the blend reporting?']

name: Larry Stranghoener
speech: ['Sure Kevin. Some of you may remember, it was only five years ago that we used to report international as a separate segment. Because of the way we manage that business, it was no longer appropriate to treat it as a second separate segment and we combined it into a phosphate segment. That is subject to review, especially given our aspirations for growth in Brazil which were described earlier.', 'That said changing segment reporting is not a trivial task and furthermore when you do have segments, the FCC really frowns on you providing financial data if that don’t comport to those segments and so we took a bit of, not a flyer but we went beyond our comfort zone today showing you this notion of manufacturing cash margins and I think it’s fair to say that we will keep you up to date on that generally, even as we revisit the question of what is the proper segmentation for the business.']

name: Jim Prokopanko
speech: ['And here on second PhosChem question, Rick McLellan is the leader of our PhosChem operations and can speak to, what was behind that?']

name: Rick McLellan
speech: ['Frankly there was—this is an organization that’s been around for 39 years and has done some really yeomen’s work in developing market places around the world for us. So it wasn’t an easy decision to decide to close it down at the end of the year. But did it come to the point where we were providing over 90% of the product that went in there, the volumes in the future, we look to become de minimums from our partners and so that two of us agreed that the timing was right for us to close it down.']

name: Jim Prokopanko
speech: ['And if you are looking for a parallels to other associations like Canpotex, PhosChem doesn’t have any assets. We ship out of separate ports. We don’t have any common freight systems. The people that sell PhosChem products around the world are Mosaic employees. So for—I think last year it was 6% to 7% was the other company’s product, just extra pounding, more work. It wasn’t going to be change so we just wound it up.']

name: Bill Carroll
speech: ['Bill Carroll for UBS. A couple of questions, one on the proposed ammonia plant expansion, have you narrowed down the range of options available to you for securing natural gas supply and then secondly with the Ma’aden JV moving forward, what you are thinking with further developing the Florida mines given the potential environmental issues there?']

name: Jim Prokopanko
speech: ['Joc, do you want to speak to the price risk on the gas contracts?']

name: Joc O'Rourke
speech: ['Yes, we have examined a number of ways of buying natural gas on the long term, one of which of course was to try and get long term contract with one of the major suppliers. We haven’t found one that works too, mutual beneficial to both parties. So at this stage we are not pursuing that. So it will be a normal market-type purchase, whether it’s a forward curve or spot buying but that can always change in the future, if we can find the counterparty that wants to make a different kind of deal.', 'And your question about the mining in Florida, it’s not going to impact our mining. The three new mines that we have in the permitting process are going to continue. This is going to be incremental tones we get from Ma’aden. So our plan is to continue to produce about 10 million tons of finished phosphates in Florida. To do that we are going to need all the—we are going to need the three mines permitted, approximately 16 to 17 million tons of ore that we extract annually will go into our processing facilities in Louisiana and Florida.', 'The result is we have to keep that 60 million ton rate. What historically has been the case with these assets is we’re permitted seven years out, eight years out, and we’ll continue that, keep enough permitted land to keep our Florida operations, Louisiana operations fully operating with of course the Peruvian rock that comes in. So no short answer, no impact on mining in Florida. The question Vincent Andrews upfront? Somebody has a one back, has a microphone back there. Go ahead. Then Vincent.']

name: Matthew Korn
speech: ['Matthew Korn at Barclays. Just a question regarding China. No matter how the Russian Belarusian situation may play out, I presume that you’re going to remain as competitive as possible in that market. Now looking what you’re doing in your spend in Brazil, which I kind read is you’re solidifying, leveraging, as you put your home field advantage. Is there any logic or potential benefit that you could see from more spending on infrastructure assets, personnel, anything which you could do there in the Chinese market to maybe take some of that home field advantage and make is portable?']

name: Jim Prokopanko
speech: ['The Chinese market values having a variety of portfolio, balanced portfolio of suppliers. And knowing how they think about securing supply, they are not likely to go to a single supplier or even two suppliers. And this is what’s happened this last couple of months, is proof to them again, why that’s such a good idea. The Canadian suppliers reliable contract integrity, quality of products, reliability of shipping, we get it done. And there is more surprises that comes to them from other suppliers. So it’s a big country, its massive 400 million farmers. It’s a real challenge. We like to have a foothold in China but China and Chinese business, they’re often for the Chinese.', 'In Brazil we have, at the end of the stick or the end of the supply chain and the Chinese farmers you maybe five or six acres. That’s pretty good bar. We’re talking 10,000 hector, 100,000 hector farms. So in terms of attractiveness we’d rather take a shipload of product, move it in country, move a couple of truckloads number of truckloads and then avoid 5 kilogram bags the individual farmers in China. So it’s a tough market. Rick would you add anything to the?']

name: Rick McLellan
speech: ['No, we’ve always had some in country capabilities so that if the chance that the market allowed us to distribute further, we’d look at that. And right now it is in the hands of politicians. When that clears out we’ll look at opportunities and we’re positioned to expand there.']

name: Jim Prokopanko
speech: ['Okay, Vincent has the microphone.']

name: Vincent Andrews
speech: ['Vincent Andrews from Morgan Stanley again. Just looking at MicroEssentials, could you talk a little bit about the industry structure maybe here in North American as well as in South America, how many other competitors are there? Are they selling products that are identical to your or similar to yours? And how does that evolve from a pricing perspective as well when you look at what others are charging?']

name: Jim Prokopanko
speech: ['Rick, would you speak to that?']

name: Rick McLellan
speech: ['Yes, right now, there is kind of two other sources that are coming to market. Neither one of them has any agronomic background to backup what they’re bringing to market. So in effect they’re bringing sulfur products and phosphate products. In comparisons in field they can’t hold a candle to what we’re doing. So we expect overtime that to change. But right now given the data that we have, given the position we have, we’re able to continue to strengthen margins and volumes.']

name: Jim Prokopanko
speech: ['It’s a bit of a threat and its bit of a bother. There is some pricing pressure. But understand this is a product that started over 10 years, development started over 10 years ago. There was a product that was owned by Cargill and came over when Mosaic was created, field trials agronomists working on it, understanding how to produce it. We blew up one phosphate plant trying to figure that out last week, another small blend plant in Saskatchewan owned by a small retailer, blew that up because of sulfur. Sulfur dust is highly, highly explosive. So we understand how to make this stuff. We understand how to sell the stuff. We have the scientific, the agronomic studies on it. And so people are saying geez, I am getting this pressure let’s put a jab of sulfur in this, they use a shell company patent and we’re producing over 1 million tons, nearly 2 million tons of product. We will be over 2.5. Others are selling 200,000 tons and they are going to find it’s a hassle. We can do it to scale it and means a lot to us. My forecast is they’re going to get bothered by this and say it’s just worth of trouble at some point.']

name: Mark Connelly
speech: ['Mark Connelly, CLSA again. Two questions. First with respect to your debt target, in order to lock in long term rates now, do you need a discrete event, do you need either M&A or K3 or Faustina to go through or is the buybacks and spending that you already have in your plants enough to put you in a position to start locking in these rates within long term bonds?']

name: Jim Prokopanko
speech: ['We have stated our plans to go to the debt market yet this year. We still expect to do that and we have hedged a lot of the interest rate risk already. So that is behind us. That is done at favorable rates relative to today’s market.']

name: Mark Connelly
speech: ['And have you done this much as you are going to do in your mind under…']

name: Jim Prokopanko
speech: ['We are unlikely to do more than we currently have done. We are hedged to a great extent. We think we are hedged to an appropriate extent given the likely size of the bond offering that we will do.']

name: Mark Connelly
speech: ['And one last question I am just back from my 12th investor trip to China and I haven’t met anyone in China who feels there is a meaningful amount of price sensitivity to the price of potash in a range of 25% up or down. I wonder if any of you can comment on who you see and where in the world there might be more or less price hit because of that?']

name: Jim Prokopanko
speech: ['Good question and I will take that and that will be the last question because Laura Gagnon is giving me what’s verging on rude hand signals, ending this. And that is the point that some people just completely didn’t get. There is price sensitivity. When you have $1,000 potash people will use less. When you $300 * $400 potash the cots per unit produced is not material. Farmers in North America and Latin America aren’t going to use more potash because it is a lower price. They are going to use the potash they need.', 'And I don’t know, maybe helped on the margins in India but valuation of the rupees destroyed that advantage. We are not going to see materially more potash consumed because it is or $300 versus $400 and for $250 or $200 and I think most people really understand that. So Rick said $100 change in potash price in North America means $0.07 a bushel on $0.07 of unit class per bushel of corn, not going to change what they use.', 'With that, you know where to reach us, you know where to reach Laura and Anton. Thanks very much. It has been a great program. Thanks for the attendance. Thank you']

name: Robert Lumpkins
speech: ["Good evening, ladies and gentlemen. I am Bob Lumpkins, Chairman of the Board of Directors of The Mosaic Company, and I'll be chairing today's meeting. It's my pleasure to take part in this ninth Annual Meeting of the stockholders of Mosaic, and to extend a special welcome to our stockholders, not only those in the room, but those also joining us via the web in our Virtual Shareholder Meeting. We appreciate your support and interest in Mosaic and are pleased you're able to be with us today.", "This Annual Meeting is now called to order. Joining me on the platform are Jim Prokopanko, President and Chief Executive of Mosaic; Rich Mack, Mosaic's Executive Vice President, General Counsel and Corporate Secretary, who will serve as secretary of this Annual Meeting.", "In addition, I want to take this opportunity to introduce Mosaic's Board of Directors. I'd ask that each of the directors or director nominee, stand when I call his or her name, and remain standing until all are introduced.", "Phyllis E. Cochran, Retired, former President and Chief Executive of Officer of Navistar Financial; Nancy E. Cooper, Retired, former Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of CA, Incorporated; Gregory L. Ebel, President and Chief Executive Officer of Spectra Energy Corporation; William R. Graber, Retired, former Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of McKesson Corporation; Emery N. Koenig, Executive Vice President and Chief Risk Officer, a member of the Corporate Leadership Team of Cargill Incorporated; Harold H. MacKay, Counsel to the law firm of MacPherson Leslie & Tyerman LLP of Regina; William T. Monahan, Retired, former Chairman of the Board, President and CEO of Imation Corporation; James L. Popowich, Retired, former Chief Executive Office of Elk Valley Coal Corporation; and of course, James T. Prokopanko, Mosaic's President and CEO; David T. Seaton, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Fluor Corporation; and Steven M. Seibert, Principal of Sibert Law Firm in Tallahassee, Florida.", 'I am also pleased to introduce Timothy S. Gitzel, President and Chief Executive Officer of Cameco Corporation, who is a nominee for election as a Director of The Mosaic Company.', 'As Chairman, I know how dedicated our Board is and I want to express my appreciation to all our directors for their years of service to Mosaic.', 'Let me turn the microphone now over to Jim Prokopanko to introduce his senior leadership team.']

name: James Prokopanko
speech: ["Well, thank you, Bob. It's my pleasure to introduce Mosaic's senior leadership team. With these officers please stand as I call their names. Larry Stranghoener, the Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Rich Mack, Executive Vice President, General Counsel and Corporate Secretary; Joc O'Rourke, Executive Vice President, Operations and Chief Operating Officer; Bo Davis, Senior Vice President, Phosphate Operations, located in Florida, wasn't able to join us today; Mark Kaplan, Vice President, Public affairs; Rich McLellan, Senior Vice President, Commercial; and Corrine Ricard, Senior Vice President, Human Resources.", 'Bob, back to you.']

name: Robert Lumpkins
speech: ["Thanks, Jim. Let's now turn to the formal proceedings of today's meeting, which are governed by Delaware law and our bylaws. Rich, would you please report to us the number of stockholders present in person or by proxy at this meeting?"]

name: Richard Mack
speech: ["Thank you, Bob. The appropriate notice of this meeting and proxy materials were first mailed on August 22, 2013, to stockholders of record of Mosaic's common stock on August 12, 2013. A list of stockholders eligible to vote has been available for inspection since September 23, and is available for inspection today at the registration table.", "As of the record date, there were 297,201,682 shares of our common stock and 128,759,772 shares of our Class A common stock outstanding and entitled to vote. Over 83% of Mosaic's common stock is represented here today in person or by proxy and accordingly a quorum is present. In addition, the necessary affidavit of mailing and the oath of the inspector of the election have been filed."]

name: Robert Lumpkins
speech: ['Thank you, Rich. Now, I would like to briefly review the proposals before the meeting today. The first proposal is the election of four directors; Mr. Gitzel, Mr. Graber, Mr. Koenig, and Mr. Seaton, have each been nominated to serve for a three-year term ending on the day of the Annual Stockholders Meeting to be held in the year 2016. All four of these nominations were recommended by the Board of Directors.', "The second proposal is the ratification of the appointment of KPMG LLP as The Mosaic Company's independent registered public accounting firm for the seven month period to end December 31, 2013, again as recommended by the Board of Directors. Tom Leyden and Mike Kopesky of KPMG are present us with today. Tom and Mike would you stand, so stockholders can recognize you, and we are going to have questions to ask during the Q&A session later.", "The third and final proposal is an advisory vote on executive compensation. The Board of Directors has recommended that the stockholders approve on an advisory basis, the compensation of Mosaic's named executive officers as described in the Compensation Discussion and Analysis section, the compensation tables and the related narrative disclosures and the proxy statement for this annual meeting.", "We've now reviewed the three proposals, before the meeting today. May I have a motion to approve proposal number one, the election of four directors?"]

name: Unidentified Company Representative
speech: ['So moved.']

name: Robert Lumpkins
speech: ['Is there a second?']

name: Unidentified Company Representative
speech: ['Second.']

name: Robert Lumpkins
speech: ['Is there any discussion on this proposal? May I now have a motion to approve proposal two, the ratification of the appointment of KPMG as our independent registered public accounting firm.']

name: Unidentified Company Representative
speech: ['So moved.']

name: Robert Lumpkins
speech: ['And is there a second?']

name: Unidentified Company Representative
speech: ['Second.']

name: Robert Lumpkins
speech: ["Is discussion on this proposal? May I now have a motion for approval of proposal number three, the advisory vote on the compensation of Mosaic's named executive officers?"]

name: Unidentified Company Representative
speech: ['So moved.']

name: Robert Lumpkins
speech: ['And is there a second?']

name: Unidentified Company Representative
speech: ['Second.']

name: Robert Lumpkins
speech: ["Thank you. Is there any discussion on this proposal? Most of you have returned proxies authorizing in the person's named on the proxy card to vote on your behalf, but if you wish now to revoke that proxy and vote by ballot or if you wish to vote and did not return your proxy card, please raise your hand so that our representative Nancy Chadwick, who is standing in the back of the room, may bring a ballot to you. For our stockholders who are participating in the Virtual Stockholders Meeting, you may now cast your votes electronically, if you wish to do so.", 'I now declare the polls open. Those of you, if anyone wishes to cast the ballot, please do so now. The polls will remain open for five minutes, and Ms. Chadwick will collect the ballots for balloting.', "Now, let me turn it to Jim Prokopanko, who is going to give us a recap of Mosaic's key milestones in fiscal 2013, and the future outlook for the company and the crop nutrient industry.", "Before Jim takes the podium, I want to take a moment to say that the statements made during the meeting the today will contain forward-looking statements about, among other things, future, financial and operating results. These are based on management's beliefs and expectations, as of today are subject to significant risks and uncertainties.", "Mosaic's actual results may differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements. Additional information, concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those shared today is included in our reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Jim?"]

name: James Prokopanko
speech: ['Thank you, Bob. Good morning and welcome. Thank you for being here and for your support of The Mosaic Company. This morning I am going to briefly review the progress we made in fiscal 2013. As a reminder, this will be our final Annual Meeting of Shareholders at this time of the year, because we are transitioning to a calendar year financial reporting in 2014.', "This morning I'll discuss the factors that have impacted our business and share our outlook on Mosaic's promising future. For those of you who tune in to our quarterly earnings call, this will be a familiar story, that it is no less compelling. At 2050, the world's population will swell to nearly 9 billion people. That's 75 million more million per year and 2 billion more than the current global population.", 'Rising human prosperity will accompany this growth, compounding the growing demand for food. In fact, to meet the demand, farmers will have to produce as much food over the next 50 years as they have over the full course of recorded human history. And they will do it on roughly the same amount of land that is being farmed today.', 'The challenge facing farmers seems overwhelming, but we at Mosaic believe agriculture will prevail with our help. Crop yields must increase to feed the world and balanced crop nutrients account for up to 60% of those yields.', 'Mosaic is the most powerful combination of talent, assets, global reach and innovation in the crop nutrition industry and we are at the center of the plate in feeding the world. This brings compelling opportunity for Mosaic and its employees, for our customers, for our communities, and perhaps most of all for our stockholders.', 'Mosaic made significant progress in 2013. We made important headway on our $3 billion spend in potash expansion projects. The K2 mine and mill expansion at our Esterhazy mine are complete and we are working to demonstrate the capacity. Our K3 mineshaft is progressing well and its headframe is now the tallest structure in the province of Saskatchewan.', 'Our plans provide for an increase in our annual operational capacity for finished product of approximately 5 million tons. We have deferred construction on projects that would provide approximately 2 million of these new tons, until construction costs and potash market conditions improve, which we believe will allow us to achieve higher returns on our investment. Also in potash, we started to see the economic benefit of a tolling agreement reversion, which increased our share of Canpotex shipments.', "We entered into an agreement to develop a 3.5 million ton integrated phosphate mine and granulation operation with Ma'aden and SABIC, in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. Mosaic will own 25% of the joint venture and will market approximately 25% of its production. The low-cost operations are expected to further diversify and expand our sources of phosphates and facilitate improved logistical access to key global countries, including India.", "Mosaic's MicroEssentials fertilizers continue to increase its share of sales in North America, Brazil and elsewhere. Sales were up 28% year-over-year. We plan to increase our production capacity to meet the increasing demand of MicroEssentials fertilizer.", "In Florida, our South Fort Meade mine returned to normal productivity, helping us procure phosphate rock at lower cost. Our Esterhazy mine, the world's largest potash mine, delivered excellent performance, highlighted by a record shipment month in May, the final month of our fiscal year, as we brought our new capacity into production.", 'We established and communicated our capital management philosophies as part of our strategy to deliver stronger shareholder value. We are targeting mid-2014 to reach our objectives for a more efficient balance sheet.', 'Mosaic continued its support of communities through targeted corporate giving, employee donations and volunteer work. The company once again donated approximately 1% of earnings before income taxes for community investment.', "The golf component at Streamsong, our new world-class destination resort in Central Florida, opened to great critical acclaim. The development, which will be completed with the opening of Streamsong's Lodge in January 2014, demonstrates the innovative and successful transformation of formerly mined lands.", "Finally and perhaps most important, we set another new record for safety performance in 2013. We achieved a 6% improvement in a key safety measure and that comes on the heels of record performance in 2012. Our top priority is the safety of our employees and our communities, and it's heartening to see ever fewer of them injured in the workplaces.", "I'm proud to report that despite the worldwide tumult brought on by volatility in weather and commodity markets, Mosaic delivered strong results in fiscal 2013. We generated net sales of $10 billion compared to $11.1 billion in fiscal 2012. Net earnings for the year were $1.9 billion, roughly the same as the year earlier. And our financial foundation remained exceptionally strong, at year's end we had $3.7 billion of cash on hand.", 'In the midst of our major investments to grow in the long-term, we were able to return significant capital to shareholders, beginning with the dividend paid in August 2012. We increased our annual dividend rate by 100% to $1 per share. In fiscal 2013, we paid out a total of $450 million to our shareholders.', "In 2013, we received external validation that Mosaic is performing as a world-class organization. I'd like to show you a brief video, highlighting these accomplishments. To those of you listening to our webcast today, you can review this video by visiting our online annual report. The web address is mosaicannualreport.com.", 'Thank you for reviewing that. Several factors have exacerbated the impact of weaker fundamentals during the last few months. First, the strengthening of the U.S. dollar against most major currencies, and especially the recent collapse of the Indian rupee has resulted in higher plant nutrient import prices in several key countries.', 'Second, the uncertainty caused by the breakup of BPC has frozen the global potash market and spilled over to the two other plant nutrient markets. And third, these two developments have occurred during the seasonally slow period, so distributors have had the luxury to wait to see how these events will play out. The net result is that distributors are cautious and have deferred purchases in the phase of softer prices and several market uncertainties.', 'Business conditions are tough. We knew these days will come and understanding the cyclical nature of our industry, we are well prepared for them. Our financial foundation is another important source of strength. Our $2 billion of surplus cash and significant debt capacity gives us meaningful flexibility to return capital to shareholders, invest for growth and fund our obligations.', 'Whether markets are good or bad, the Mosaic story does not change. We will continue executing the strategy we refined in 2012, because it is the right strategy for Mosaic.', "I'll briefly touch on each of our priorities. First is, people. I strongly believe that we have assembled the most talented team in our industry and we intend to maintain this critical competitive advantage by maintaining and recruiting highly talented people all across our operations.", 'Next is growth. Our potash expansions will significantly increase our operational capacity. And over the long-term, our Saudi joint venture should enable us to further diversify our sources of phosphates and provide access to key markets. And we will continue to look for value adding business development opportunities, both joint ventures and acquisitions.', "Next is market access. We're currently working to secure our existing market access, increase our presence in key agricultural regions and enter promising new areas. For example, in Brazil, one of the very few regions of the world with new acreage being brought into production, we intend to invest up to $300 million on a number of projects to build, expand or acquire distribution facilities.", 'And finally is innovation. Our product innovation continues to differentiate Mosaic from our competitors. Our MicroEssentials fertilizer reached an 11% share of the North American phosphate sales in fiscal 2013, and it is gaining traction in other regions of the world. We will continue to deliver product technology that improves yields, while helping farmers take care of the environment.', "And finally, shareholder value. We are always determined to deliver strong total shareholder returns, with a focus on execution and effective capital allocation. We have always managed Mosaic with a long-term view. Markets and weather and prices will change, and they will affect our quarterly results. But the global demand for food, the imperative for farmers across the world to produce higher crop yields, the steady increase in the earth's population, these trends will not change.", 'Mosaic is in an excellent position to help agriculture meet its daunting challenge and that bodes well for all our stakeholders. Thank you to our customers, our employees, our partners and our stockholders for your continued confidence and support. We look forward to working with you for many prosperous years ahead. Thank you very much.']

name: Robert Lumpkins
speech: ["Thank you very much, Jim. Before I turn to the voting result, I'd like to express my appreciation to Phyllis and Harold, for their years of service on the Mosaic board. Phyllis has served on the board since 2006. Harold was an original member of the Mosaic board, when we reformed in 2004, and before that he was with IMC Global and before that a predecessor company Vigoro, so he has 19 years of board experience with this company and its predecessors.", 'For both of you, we are very grateful for your experience and your insights and your friendship over these years. And your dedication to the company and to the board has been of great value. And on behalf of my board colleagues, I wish you all the best in your future endeavors.', 'Let me turn now to the announcement of the voting results. The polls have closed. Votes on the three proposals have been tabulated. Rich, as the Secretary of the meeting, could you please report the results?']

name: Richard Mack
speech: ['Mr. Chairman, I have been informed by the inspector of election that, with respect to proposal number one, each of the board nominees has received over 96% of the total votes cast in favor of his or her election to the board.', "With respect to proposal number two, ratification of KPMG as Mosaic's independent registered public accounting firm has been adopted by more than 99% of the total shares voted.", "And that with respect to proposal number three, the advisory vote on executive compensation, the compensation of Mosaic's named executive officers as described in Mosaic's proxy statement for this meeting has been approved by more than 97% of the total shares voted."]

name: Robert Lumpkins
speech: ['Thanks, Rich. Based on the results, I am pleased to declare that each, Mr. Gitzel, Mr. Graber, Mr. Koenig, Mr. Seaton, have been elected to the board for a three-year term. The appointment of KPMG, as our independent registered public accounting firm for the period ending December 31, 2013, has been ratified and the advisory vote on executive compensation has been approved.', 'Now, these final results will be recorded in the minutes of the meeting. And the final tabulation will appear in our Form 8-K to be filed early next week. That concludes the formal business for today. And I thank you for your participation in the voting process.', "At this time, Jim and I would be pleased to respond to any questions from stockholders. If you have questions or comments, please ask to be recognized, because we are webcasting today's meeting. It's important that you use the microphone to ask your questions, [indiscernible] Shawn and Carmen Kilde will bring a microphone to you. They are standing in the room. And I ask that you please begin by stating your name."]

name: Robert Lumpkins
speech: ["Are there any question? Boring ones? No questions? Well, then this concludes Mosaic's ninth Annual Meeting of Stockholders.", "Before we adjourn, I just want to express my appreciation to all of you, whether here in person or via webcast for your continuing support and for joining us at today's Annual Meeting. And I'd like to thank Mosaic's very dedicated employees and directors. Is there a motion to adjourn?"]

name: Unidentified Company Representative
speech: ['So moved.']

name: Robert Lumpkins
speech: ['Is there a second?']

name: Unidentified Company Representative
speech: ['Second.']

name: Robert Lumpkins
speech: ['This meeting is now adjourned. Thank you very much.']

name: Chris Parkinson
speech: ["I think we'll going to get started with 9:00 AM. So I'm Chris Parkinson here behalf of the Credit Suisse Agricultural Sciences Team. I'd like to thank all of you for attending our conference this week.", 'It is with distinct pleasure that I am here to introduce Mr. Jim Prokopanko, President and CEO of The Mosaic Company, with the market capital of over $19 billion. Mosaic is a leading, global producer of processed phosphate, potash, and specialty fertilizers.', "And with that, I'll turn it over to Jim, because I don't think you're here to hear me speak."]

name: James Prokopanko
speech: ['Well, good morning and thank you, Chris. Thanks for the introduction. Good morning, everybody, and thanks for the interest in Mosaic. Please note our Safe Harbor statement, so advise.', "Well, let me start today by sharing with you our view of the phosphate and potash outlook, a headline-rich industry these days. Uralkali's announcement on July 30, obviously [royal] markets and changed the perception of the global potash industry. The subsequent high drama still dominates industry news today and continues to provide intriguing [theatre], but our assessment is that the market is overreacting to these developments.", "Despite the incredible amount of analysis following the announcement, the break-up of BPC in our view does nothing to change long-term fundamentals. The long-term outlook remains positive for reasons I will highlight later and fundamentals and nothing else. We'll continue to drive the long-term outlook for both phosphate and potash.", 'That said, there is no denying that fundamentals for all three nutrients have weakened recently due to a combination of factors. Illustrating the weakened fundamentals, this Chart shows that prices for all crop nutrients have declined significantly during the last two years and long before the July 30 announcement for all major nutrients.', 'On the demand side, subsidy reductions by the Indian government have resulted in sharp increases in retail prices and significant decreases in phosphate and potash use. In addition, the agricultural commodity prices, although still elevated, have retreated from record highs last year due to the prospect of a larger global harvest this year.', 'On the supply side, several brownfield and greenfield projects are beginning to deliver new supplies to the market, and as we have noted before, supply grows in lumpy increments. A couple of years of demand growth maybe needed to fully absorb the new capacity. Finally, lower cost from some raw material such as natural gas and sulfur are helping to reduce the finished product prices.', 'Several factors have exacerbated the impact of weaker fundamentals during the last few months. First, the strengthening of the U.S. dollar against most major currencies and especially the recent collapse of the Indian rupee has increased the local currency price of imported plant nutrients and pressured dollar denominated delivery prices in several key countries.', 'Second, the uncertainty caused by the breakup of BPC has frozen the global potash market and spillover to the two other plant nutrient markets. Third, these two developments have occurred during a seasonally slow period, so distributors have had the luxury to wait to see how these events will play out.', 'The net result is that distributors are cautious and have deferred purchases in the face of softer prices and several uncertainties. So in the near-term, as announced in the press release this morning, market conditions have caused us to lower our price and volume guidance.', 'For the third calendar quarter, we now expect potash volumes in the range of 1,450,000 to 1,650,000 tons with realized MOP prices in the range of $330 to $340 per ton. Gross margin rate is now expected to be in the low-to-mid 30% range.', 'The range for phosphate volumes is 2,600,000 tons to 2,800,000 tons with realized DAP prices in the range of $430 to $440 per ton. Gross margin rate is now expected to be in the mid-teens. We estimate our tax rate for the seven-month stub year to be in the low 20% range, including notable items.', "Now, let's turn back to the fundamentals. Behind all the noise are strong demand prospects, but demand remains a tale of two hemispheres. The drop in Indian shipments has garnered most of the attention, but plant nutrient demand is outstanding in other regions where markets and global price signals are allowed to work.", 'For example, Brazil will import and use record volumes of phosphate and potash this year. North American phosphate shipment set a record in 2012-2013, and our team expects another outstanding fallout application season in North America. Global phosphate and potash shipments are projected to reach record or near record levels this year and then increase to record levels in 2014.', 'Profitable farm economics underpinned demand. Our affordability metric indicates that plant nutrients are historically cheap due to elevated commodity prices and declines in plant nutrient costs. So there is no surprise that the latest USDA estimate showed the U.S. net cash farm income will stay at extraordinarily high levels for the third year in a row.', 'Additionally, we estimate that distributors are destocking the large global pipeline this year. On-farm application appears strong, despite less than expected shipments in some regions. Even our Delhi, India team reports a decent season for farmers due to an outstanding monsoon this year and higher support prices for major crops. Swings in distribution channel inventories only amplify fundamental developments.', 'Finally, delayed purchases are expected to compress movement this fall and likely test transportation and logistics capabilities. Prices for nearly all major plant nutrients have declined to their lowest levels in about three years, but we believe these factors point to a bottom.', 'As I noted earlier, the events of the last few months have not changed our long-term outlook. The food story remains intact. We recently updated our long-term grain and oilseed forecasts. This indicates that annual global harvest will need to increase by about 350 million tons between now and the end of the decade in order to meet projected demand.', 'To put that in perspective, this increase is roughly equal to the combined and outstanding harvest of Argentina, Brazil and Canada in 2012. We call this the ABCs of our food story.', 'Our analysis shows that farmers will need to plant record area and reap record yields year-after-year in order to meet projected demand. More hectares and even higher yields will require more plant nutrients. In fact, with the help of our international distribution team, we recently updated our long-term phosphate and potash demand forecasts.', 'We project that global shipments of the main finished phosphates products will increase 2.8% per year this decade or from 58.7 million tons in 2010 to 77.8 million tons in 2020. In the case of potash, we forecast that MOP shipments will increase 2.9% per year this decade or from 52.6 million tons in 2010 to 70.3 million tons in 2020.', 'Based on these demand forecasts as well as our estimates of our operating capacities these Charts show a long-term global operating rates for the main finished products as well as myriad of potash markets. Projected rates -- operating rates do not hit the extraordinary peaks of last decade, but they also do not indicate a prolonged or deep cyclical downturn. Our conclusion is that they show a balanced and constructive fundamental outlook through the end of this decade.', "Before I talk about Mosaic strategy, I feel compelled to respond to several mischaracterizations of both the global potash market as well as our operations. The first is how potash markets work. We've always maintained that potash prices are determined by supply and demand. A brief review of prices during the last couple of decades supports this assessment.", "Second the economic rationale for legal export associations such as Canpotex's efficiency. Canpotex delivers value to member companies through cost savings from its world-class transportation and logistics operations as well as its best-in-class customer service from a specialized and experience sales and marketing staff. Finally, despite several industry cost curves published during the last two months, Mosaic's global scale potash operations are cost competitive, and I'll give you more background on that shortly.", "Let's take a look at potash prices over time. This Chart shows that potash prices and margins were flat at low levels until about 2004. The prolonged period of low prices and margins was largely the result of the break-up of the former Soviet Union in 1991. These Chart show the collapse of domestic potash shipments and the new supply of product that flooded the market. The old adage that the cure for low prices is low prices and the cure for high prices is high prices, applies in the global potash market.", "Potash fundamentals and prices began to change in 2003. In fact, global MOP demand surged 30% or 12.6 million tons between 2002 and 2007. High soybean prices coupled with the weak real, super charged Brazil's agricultural sector. High oilseed prices also drove the rapid development of palm oil production in Southeast Asia.", 'China and India, also made significant progress in achieving more balanced nutrient use during that period. The surge in demand coupled with atrophy supply capabilities from years of underinvestment in this sector caused the 2008 price spike.', 'I simply cringe when I read reports that attribute despite the production cutbacks. I can tell you that we were scooping every spoonful of potash out of the earth that we could in the order to meet raging demand. In fact, most of our customer complaints were not about prices, but rather delays in shipping product, because we simply could not keep pace with demand.', 'Industry and statistics indicate that other producers faced similar challengers. Fundamentals have changed and prices have moderated during the last years due to the slowdown in demand growth and the commissioning of brownfield capacity by several producers.', "Finally, we believe several recent studies have mischaracterized our cost position. This Chart from the 2013 CRU cost study provides consistent estimates for all producers running at capacity, and we believe captures Mosaic's relative cost position on the industry cost curve.", 'For our fiscal year that ended on May 31, we produced 7.2 million tons of MOP at our three facilities in Saskatchewan and our average mine production cost was in the $125 to $135 per ton range. Treatment of freight and resource taxes as well as impact of the tolling agreement need to be considered in order to properly assess our cost position. Our costs are elevated due to approximately $240 million of annual brine management cost at our Esterhazy facility.', 'Excluding these, our costs are comparable to the average cost of other Saskatchewan producers, but are 15% to 20% greater than the average for FSU producers, who benefit from lower labor and lower energy costs. So our actual delivered cost last year, including brine management cost were in the $180 to $185 per ton range for sales to China and were in the $200 to $205 per range for sales to Brazil.', "Our costs are as not as high as several recent estimates, but we recognize they are elevated relative to key competitors. We are identifying opportunities for improvement and we'll provide more details about these initiatives at our Analyst Day here in New York on October 7.", "Bringing all of this together, there has been an overreaction to the BPC break-up announcement. But there is also no denying that near-term fundamentals have been weakened, given several supply and demand related factors. Our long-term outlook remains positive, underpinned by solid farm economics, and Mosaic's cost position is competitive even with the brine inflow costs.", 'So with that background, our strategy has not changed. We refined our priorities last year and we are executing well. We have five principal priorities. First is, people. We are investing people in people and most importantly their safety, so that Mosaic is a place where people want to build their carriers.', "Second, in growth. We are investing heavily in growth, including our potash expansions and our joint venture in Saudi Arabia and while we're seeking other strategic growth opportunities. The own innovation, number three. Our MicroEssential product and its fast growing market share demonstrate our product innovation. We're also strongly committed to process innovation that saves money and increases our sustainability.", "Fourth is, market access. We're consistently working to secure our existing market access and increase our reach to the global markets. If we execute well on all four of these priorities, shareholder value will follow.", 'Our financial foundation provides a meaningful competitive advantage. We have the cash and debt capacity to withstand tough times, meet our obligations and investor growth and to return capital to shareholders. As you all know, we are unable to purchase shares in the open market until after November 26 of this year. We wish we could be buying shares today.', "All of our strategic priorities contribute to our goal, which is to generate strong total shareholder returns. We have the strongest combination of assets, financial stability, talent, global reach, and innovation in the crop nutrient industry. We're in excellent position to be the world's leading crop nutrition company.", "With that, thank you for your attention. And I think I'm available to take a few questions."]

name: Chris Parkinson
speech: ["Thank you, Jim. I'll just start off with a quick question based on your recent guidance cuts, particularly in the phosphate market. A lot of us have been paying attention to the situation in India, but looking at continued strength in Brazil, are there any other trends we should be looking at in particular pertaining to the third quarter, and what your expectations are for the balance of the year and into 2014?"]

name: James Prokopanko
speech: ["I think it's a -- you've identified the two key drivers. What is happening in India and that has a knock-on effect in that reduced Indian demand, largely driven by a distorting market subsidy system. Farmer support system has reduced the demand for phosphates. That in turn has dried up an important market for the Chinese, who have India as a prime market.", "And that product that used to go to India from China is now going to Brazil. That's challenged the pricing in Brazil, but with that, we are expecting with the weaker real, strong soybean prices denominated in U.S. dollars, demand will be strong for the second crop that will be following the soybean. So, we look for outstanding industry fundamentals in Brazil this year and likely next year.", "And then there will be the U.S. market this year, which is delayed in part because of a late developing crop, but when it does come, we think it's going to be a remarkable fall season in North America, and then beyond that, I don't have anything else to add. Maybe costs we're seeing, sulfur cost stable, ammonia cost stable-to-lower certainly from where they were a couple of months ago. So just don't be focused on the sale price. Understand that we've seen ingredient costs, sulfur, ammonia come down."]

name: Chris Parkinson
speech: ["It's the view of one of your competitors that lower price will bring about a significant rise in potash demand. I think the number was something like 6 million tons. To what degree do you agree with this? And I guess kind of -- at what price do you see some of your larger customers coming back into the market in a bigger way?"]

name: James Prokopanko
speech: ["I don't share the -- it's our view, my view. I don't agree with that perspective. The potash market is a largely priced inelastic market, and certainly at the high-end, you might see some price elasticity, $800, $1,000. But certainly in the mid-range to lower-range, I don't think you're going to stoke more demand with $300 potash versus $400 potash.", "It's all about the grain prices and certainly grain prices relative to fertilizer -- to potash prices whether $300 or $400 is very inducive to application of potash. So, I don't see a drop in prices as materially changing global potash demand in any one year or any one season, not at all.", "And your second question was at what price do we see major customers coming back, I mean that's what you'd asked. I think this is great economic reason to apply potash. The market that's in question remains India, and with the Indian potash crop nutrient subsidy system, where nitrogen is heavily incented by a factor of virtually 3x to potash and phosphate.", "I don't think you're going to see India come back to the traditional or historic potash demand of about 6 million tons until that subsidy program is resolved or adjusted. That won't happen, I don't believe, very unlikely it will happen before early or the first half of 2014 where we're awaiting Indian Federal election. The result would be if they change the subsidy system, they'd have to reduce the subsidy that they pay for nitrogen.", "Nitrogen is a domestically produced product largely in India. Reducing the subsidy would be effectively increasing the price of nitrogen to farmers, and nobody is going to do that before an election. So, we just don't see any light at the end of that tunnel until next year.", "Now, I think as the markets resolved and we understand what's happening in Eastern Europe with the potash producers, this is -- these prices -- this is an opportunity for anybody interested in long-term contracts to load up on potash, and we'll see if people don't miss that opportunity."]

name: Chris Parkinson
speech: ["Question regarding your comments on the announcements and the (inaudible) at BPC. By your own graphs, you're suggesting that the potash utilization in some markets is going to remain 15% to 20% idled capacity supporting higher prices. In most markets that's not sufficient leverage if you will to support the very high margins that we see in the business. With that and in light of the fact that your demand must be pretty robust to absorb of all of the growth in production that's been announced, how do you reconcile that with no change in long-term fundamentals. Is it -- or maybe the direct question is, is it necessary for that capacity utilization to get pushed up into the 90s to support prices at or above where they are today?"]

name: James Prokopanko
speech: ["The important question you're asking, and it comes down to the understanding of what operational capacity is. Operational capacity in this industry is often established as the best you can produce, the most you can produce in a 90-day proving run, at least for Canpotex purposes, multiply that by four and you get your annual operating rates. So run it for 90 days, three consecutive months. The best you can do actually is you run it for four months. You see the best you can do in 90 days, that becomes your operational rate. Well, potash mines don't run like that.", "So, we have adjusted operating capacities, say, look that's not real, you have at least one month turnaround at most mines and facilities, at least the one month to turnaround. So you don't operate a mine, although rate at a 100% capacity, you don't run it for 12 months, you run it for 11 months. Then you have unexpected, so at least 90% of what your operating rate is the effective capacity.", 'Running at that rate is like running at a 100% and that just is impossible. You take down unexpected outages, plant shut downs, power interruptions. These things do happen with mining operations, so I think running at 90% capacity is equivalent for an extended period of time is equivalent to running at a 100%.', "So we see 85% to 90% operating rates. We're going to see strong-to-elevated prices. We get over 90% operating rates for any period of time I think we're going to have strongly appreciated potash prices. So it all comes down to what is that denominator, what is in fact the operating rates. And these operating rates were often established when that mine was built. So, we have an operating rate at Esterhazy that was established 50 years ago.", "Any mining, any basic materials industry starts with high grading the product, you go to the richest deposit. Over time, capacity starts to decline. You get further and further away from the richest store body. So just by way of an example, when Esterhazy, our largest potash mine -- the largest potash mine, the largest underground mine in the world was established 50 years ago, we're lifting just under 3 tons of ore to produce 1 ton of MOP finished product.", "Today, we are approaching 4 tons of ore to produce 1 ton of finished product, just making the point that these operating capacities, there is some fiction in them. They are not entirely accurate, and overtime those operating capacities just really aren't there. So I think we have a period of slack, absolutely, might be another 12 months, 18 months, 24 months, but I think we're going to get back into balance quickly, and I'm not too fussed by it, we'll get back there."]

name: Chris Parkinson
speech: ['I think anyone following Mosaic wants to hear you talk about Uralkali a little bit, so I want to just talk about that for a second. It looks like what happened in late 2012 was that Canpotex had a deal with China that spooked BPC, and then both Uralkali and Belaruskali, kind of started shipping out the back door, discipline was lost and here we are with first half results for Uralkali being down 40% on EBITDA and close to 20% revenue and pricing declines.', "So it looks like they're going to try to get back the five points of share that they have lost to Canpotex in the first half of this year. Could you talk about the prospects for Mosaic in light of that market share grab back? And let's ask the magic question, do you think they're going to get back together and if they do who cares?"]

name: James Prokopanko
speech: ["Well, some of that replay of history is one interpretation in China with Canpotex responded to the pricing in the market. We've seen competitors that had access to overland rail into Northern China, very, very aggressive. That seems to be missing from the narrative one of the producers.", "They were very aggressive to this day time moving about the 2,000 tons a month at ghastly low prices. Good, perhaps back -- net backs, but to world prices -- below world prices. So I don't agree with your replay of what the history was that they responded to Canpotex. Canpotex was being competitive in the marketplace and with seaborne shipments is our only access into China.", "We are going to lose market share or they're going to grab market share back. It's my view and I spend a lot of time with the international customers. I was recently with a large group of them from Asia for about three or four days on a customer event. And there is nobody in the world that provides customer care, customer attention, contract integrity that does -- that's provided by Canpotex and its Canadian shareholders, producing shareholders. And the customers recognize that.", "So going forward, we're going to standby our core key customers. We have many of them in Asia, we have some -- I was recently in Asia and visiting with one of the customers and with our sales rep to that customer, who was there when this palm plantation planted their first palm tree, 25 years, 27 years ago.", "This person is 100% -- this large, large customer is a 100% Canpotex. They won't think for a minute going to the Russian producer, provided we're competitive. So we have core customers, not all our customers are core customers, some are transactional. But we are going to stick by our core customers and we are going to ensure that they are competitive and price -- market share will be where the market share is.", "So third question BPC, are they going to get back together, I just -- I know as much as you do. I don't think a volume overprice strategy passes the economic sniff test to use more of a non-renewable resource to bring it to market at a lower price, greater volume, so that you earn less dollars. Somebody has to come and explain, pencil out that math to me.", 'I think what you want to do is maximize the price you can get for a product, to justify the kind of returns we need today for capital reinvestment and for a brownfield reinvestment to justify brownfield, you need a minimum of $300 a ton FOB mine price to justify a cost to capital return on investment.', "For greenfield, which we're going to need a greenfield mine some time in the year 2020, 2023, you're going to need $600 a ton. So giving it away, I don't understand whose benefit it serves. It doesn't serve the shareholders purpose. It doesn't serve the enterprises purpose. You can't justify growth in the industry.", "So I just don't see that what we have today is a one competitive strategy of volume overprice is sustainable for very long at all. And I think when the dust settles and within a year, we're going to find that there isn't much more potash sold, market shares haven't changed appreciably and somebody is going to have a lot of explaining to do."]

name: Unidentified Analyst
speech: ["Jim, I think you made a very good case for the value of Canpotex, legal export association until the recent brouhaha with BPC however, it seemed like all the major world producers would come into line, when one big group negotiate a price with China or whatever, everyone else would seem to go in line with that. Does that mean, it's more than just Canpotex, is it export association or it's bigger than that or has there been any pressure from the authorities in Canada asking about this, just a curious?"]

name: James Prokopanko
speech: ["So in Canada, it's a legal association under the laws of Canada, but there is similar kind of associations permitted in the U.S. and it is a collective marketing, and most importantly the collective logistic. So in Canada, there is tremendous support both at the federal and at the prudential level for the value that Canpotex brings and our customers like Canpotex. That says it all.", "The customers that we have, our core customers know that we have contract integrality, know that most of the executives are free, walking around, traveling the world and not in some -- not under detention. They can meet with me in my office or in their office. They don't have to come on visiting day. Does that sense a lot, just think about it, you're going -- you are going to put your hand -- your food security for your country in the hands of a company that you don't know who owns it, you don't know the legal position of the chief executive and their staff.", 'Are you going to do business with people like that -- it just shake my head. So as I say, customers that we do business with around the world really appreciate the value that Canpotex brings both in costs, logistics and security and supply. I just really think that Canpotex service a lot of people extremely well.']

name: Chris Parkinson
speech: ["If I could just sneak in the last question, and we appreciate your remarks, if you did -- and sitting in this room are obviously your shareholders and a lot of potential shareholders, if you could leave them with a few thoughts. I mean, if you're in either my shoes or their shoes, what analysis would you be doing or what do you think has been missed opportunity, when evaluating the intrinsic value of their stock?"]

name: James Prokopanko
speech: ["We'll do the math. First of all, consider what it would cost just to replace Mosaic today. You're going to and we're going through it now, we're investing in a joint venture in Saudi Arabia, 3.5 million, 3 million ton finish phosphate plant. That's going to cost something approaching $7 billion with an ammonia plant. So lets call it, forget the ammonia plant, just take it out $2,000 -- $6 billion, $2,000 a capacity ton to develop a mine and a phosphate plant. We produce 10 million tons of phosphate a year.", "To replace Mosaic's phosphate business, with 40 years proven probable reserves, it's going to cost you 10 million tons times $2,000 a ton, $20 billion. To build a new potash mine, it's costing at least $2,500 a capacity ton to build a new greenfield facility. We have 100 years of reserves at already. We produce and we'll with the finish our -- with the completion of the Esterhazy expansion, we'll be producing 13 million tons at $2,500 a ton, little hard amount, that's 26 plus 7, that's $30 billion.", "So we have a $30 billion replacement value of potash, $20 billion replacement value of phosphate, $50 billion at distribution business worth of couple of billion. Goodwill, talented staff, trained people and $3.5 billion on our balance sheet, we're $60 billion enterprise and it's trading at $20 billion -- under $20 billion, that just doesn't make sense.", "So if you're looking for an investment for the next three and four months, well you can throw the dice. If you're looking for an investment that you can be confident that over the next three, five, 10, 15, 20 years is going to be secure -- value is going to be realized, it's going to be in Mosaic.", "You can't replace Mosaic today for under $60 billion and for to be trading at $20 billion that's a real frustration and that's the way the market spoke and that's what they say. But it is a valuable piece of property and it's not just a single nutrient product like some companies are, they've got a one trick pony, it's just nitrogen, it's just potash, it's just phosphate. They each have their day.", "And I think the day like -- market likes a day where there is challenges in the potash industry, although, passing and temporary. We have potash, we have phosphate, nutrients that are hard to get, saying we have at the Mosaic, its all about the rock. And they are just isn't cheap, accessible rock whether it's potash or whether it's phosphate for anyone to get in the business and create that kind of value that we can create and deliver.", 'Thanks, Chris. Thanks for this opportunity very much. Look forward to seeing many of this, afternoon.']

name: Operator
speech: ["Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to The Mosaic Company's fourth quarter and fiscal year 2013 earnings conference call. At this time all participants have been placed in a listen-only mode. After the company concludes their prepared remarks, the lines will be opened to take your questions. Your host for today's call is Laura Gagnon, Vice President, Investor Relations of The Mosaic Company. Ms. Gagnon?"]

name: Laura Gagnon
speech: ["Thank you, and welcome to our fourth quarter and fiscal year 2013 earnings call. Presenting today will be Jim Prokopanko, President and Chief Executive Officer and Larry Stranghoener, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. We also have members of the senior leadership team available to answer your questions after our prepared remarks. After my introductory comments, Jim will review Mosaic's accomplishments for the quarter and year and our views on current and future market conditions. Larry will provide an update on our capital management and share insights into our future expectations. The presentation slides we are using during the call are available on our website at mosaicco.com.", "We will be making forward-looking statements during this conference call. The statements include but are not limited to, statements about future financial and operating results. They are based on management's beliefs and expectations as of today’s date, July 16, 2013, and are subject to significant risks and uncertainties. Actual results may differ materially from projected results. Factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements are included in our press release issued this morning and in our reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.", 'Now I would like to turn it over to Jim.']

name: James Prokopanko
speech: ['Good morning. Welcome to our fiscal fourth quarter and full year earnings discussion. Mosaic delivered a great fourth quarter. Thanks in part to a very strong albeit late and compressed spring application season in North America, as well as record Canpotex shipments. Demand for our products remains strong in many parts of the world with the exception of India. This morning I will review the quarter and the fiscal year then Larry will provide guidance and an update on our capital spending. And then before we take your questions, I will discuss our outlook for the coming year.', "We would like you to take away three key messages today. First, Mosaic continues to execute and deliver solid performance, quarter after quarter. Second, we have completed a great year of progress in fiscal 2013. And finally, Mosaic remains in excellent position to achieve our vision of being the world's leading crop nutrition company. Let's start with the fiscal fourth quarter.", 'We reported operating earnings of $621 million on net sales of $2.7 billion. Both down compared with a year ago due to lower prices for potash and phosphates. The potash business unit contributed $445 million of operating earnings and the phosphates business unit contributed $198 million. In total, we reported earnings per share of $1.14, compared with $1.19 a year ago, an outstanding outcome in light of external factors.', 'We generated $855 million in operating cash flow during the quarter and we continue to maintain a strong cash position with $3.7 billion of cash on hand. Those numbers don’t tell the full story. It was a tough spring planting season for farmers here in North America. Warm weather came very late and just six months after drought battered the 2012 crop, the spring of 2013 brought [thrashing] rains to most of the Corn Belt. Some of the same fields that our ploughed under for lack of rain last year were puddled and too wet for planting this year.', "The Mississippi River, once so dry that navigation nearly came to a halt, was again difficult to navigate this time because of flooding. Despite the logistical challenges, Mosaic's excellent execution allowed us to have product where it was needed to be for a very compressed and late application season in North America. In fact, we sold 2.6 million tons of potash, a record quarter for Mosaic. And 2.9 million tons of phosphates with a big finish in the last two weeks of May.", 'Shipments were also strong outside North America. We delivered record shipments to Brazil. We have reached an agreement on phosphate contracts with customers in India. And Canpotex had its best March through May period ever due to high volumes to China and Brazil as well as strong potash shipments to Southeast Asia. The strong demand led to high operating rates in our facilities. Our potash mines operated at 95% of capacity, while the phosphates operating rate was 85% of capacity.', "As we have always said, markets determine prices and potash and phosphate prices were lackluster for two market driven reasons. First, India continues to use significantly less potash than it has in recent history, offsetting demand growth elsewhere. As a result of the nation's unbalanced subsidy program, Indian agricultural soil is suffering and at some point the subsidies will need to change to avoid increasing pressure on the food supply. India will come back, we are just not certain when.", 'Second, additional supply is expected to come on the market with China and Saudi Arabia providing some new phosphate tons, and potash expansions coming online in Canada and Russia. We expect this softness which is exacerbated by the weak Indian rupee to continue over the near term. We have often said that volumes increase first followed by prices, and we expect that trend to continue. We have experienced two years without volume growth until now, volume is growing again. That demand growth will absorb supply and at some point prices will follow.', 'That said, North America upcountry prices held up well during the quarter, in part because of the logistical challenges posed by the weather. We were able to overcome those challenges with our final price deferred arrangements with some customers. These arrangements allow customers to fill their bins early and then price this inventory closer to when the product is sold. Mosaic and our customers jointly capture value at the point of retail sale, which has created significant goodwill and customer loyalty. It also enables us to maintain our production at an efficient and steady rate because it can move product to retailers before their customers are demanding it.', 'Beyond our excellent fourth quarter performance, the longer term outlook remains positive. Farmers still have strong incentive to maximize yield. And to maximize yield, they need fertilizer. Grain and oil seed prices have declined in anticipation of a big crop, which would be a welcome development for global food security. But prices remain high enough to deliver good farm profits, especially given the affordability of crop nutrition and other inputs. And let’s not forget that farmers balance sheets and cash flows remain exceptionally strong as a result of many years of compelling economics.', 'Farmers can make a good living even if corn prices drift down to $4.50 or even $4 per bushel, especially if they’re wringing more bushels out of each acre. Revenue per acre matters to farmers and there are a lot of ways to generate a profitable $900 of revenue per acre. So as farmers push for better yields, Mosaic can in turn generate strong returns even with lower grain and oil seed prices. One further note on grain and oil seed prices. We do not expect prices to suffer dramatically. Just as $7 corn did strong by destroying demand last year, we expect lower prices to unleash significant pent up demand for grain and oil seed this year, which should raise the floor under prices.', 'So to summarize our fiscal fourth quarter. Mosaic once again delivered on its promises and expectations. We executed well, mitigating the impact of extraordinary circumstances which enabled us to produce results that were in line with our guidance. I am very proud of what our team accomplished. We manage the company for long term success and our consistent quarterly performance is evidence of this focus.', 'Now, I will step back and talk about our full year. We made great progress throughout our fiscal year. Despite a tumultuous period marked by wild weather swings, shifting government policies and significant volatility in agricultural commodity prices, Mosaic took big steps forward while generating steady, solid results. I’d like to recount some highlights. Our first priority is the safety of our employees. I’m proud to report that we set another record for safety performance in 2013, which is a reflection of our operational excellence. We achieved a 6% improvement in our key safety measures and that comes on the heels of record performance in 2012. We made good progress on our Potash expansion projects, which remained on budget and on time. In Potash, we started to see the economic benefit of the tolling agreement reversion, which increased our allocation of Canpotex by 6 percentage points.', 'The Saudi joint venture is proceeding well. The next step is the signing of a shareholders agreement. When production begins likely in late 2016, the project will be an important new source of low cost phosphate fertilizer for us. We extended our market leadership in innovative, yield enhancing crop nutrition products. Mosaic’s MicroEssentials phosphate product continued to gain market share in North America, Brazil and elsewhere. In fact, shipments were up 28% year over year. We plan to increase our production capacity to meet the strong demand for MicroEssentials.', 'In Florida, our South Fort Meade mine returned to full productivity, helping us generate phosphate rocks at lower cost. We received the Army Corps of Engineers Area-wide Environmental Impact Study regarding our phosphate acreage in Central Florida. We believe the AEIS report is a positive stepping stone as we work towards new mine permits.', 'Finally, we established and communicated explicit philosophies for capital management as part of our strategy to deliver strong shareholder value. That’s quite a year and we accomplished all these things while generating $1.9 billion in cash from operations, $2.2 billion in operating earnings and $10 billion in net sales.', 'Now, I’ll turn the call over to Larry. After he provides further discussion of our capital plans and our guidance, I will conclude with a walk of the remainder of 2013 and beyond. Larry?']

name: Lawrence Stranghoener
speech: ['Thanks Jim and good morning. We’ve talked to you frequently in recent months about our capital philosophy, so rather than reiterate all that information, I’ll provide a couple of relevant updates. First, we have had discussions regarding the Class A shares held by the Margaret A. Cargill Trust and Cargill family members. As we announced in a news release on June 25, Cargill Incorporated has elected not to allow the amendment of agreements that would have permitted accelerated share repurchases, and the trusts have elected to forego their right to demand a secondary equity offering at this time. It is our intention to pursue share repurchases or repurchases combined with the secondary offering, after November 26 of this year when we are no longer governed by split off related restrictions.', 'We continue to target mid-2014 to hit our stated balance sheet objectives, which include an adjusted debt to EBITDA ratio of 1.5 times and a liquidity buffer of $2.25 billion. Second, we are planning to access the debt markets when conditions are right. It is reasonable to expect the bond offering during the second half of 2013 to take advantage of historically attractive debt market conditions.', 'Now I will turn to guidance. We are delighted this is the last time we will be reporting under the May 31 fiscal year-end. As I am sure you are aware, we will change our fiscal year-end to December 31, and are currently in a 7-month stub period. Beginning with this call, we will provide quarterly and annual guidance on a calendar basis so the quarterly guidance I will go through now is intended to cover July through September of this year.', "One final note on our fiscal year change. We intend to release our historical financial results recast on a calendar basis in September when we will provide results for calendar quarters going back to the first quarter of 2012. Our price and volume guidance reflects Jim's comments. This has been a year of volume recovery with prices impacted by a number of factors including the Indian rupee's weakness, contract negotiations with China, and generally cautious customer behavior. We expect strong volumes to continue and as Jim said, we expect prices to follow when these market issues are resolved.", 'For the third quarter of calendar 2013, we expect potash sales volumes to be in the range of 1.8 to 2.1 million tons compared with actual volumes of 1.8 million tons in the same period of last year.
